header_summary:
Jonas Nick addresses the privacy vulnerabilities inherent in the distributed key generation (DKG) process for Bitcoin, specifically focusing on the plaintext exposure of recovery data, including participants' public keys and the final threshold public key. This revelation poses a risk to user privacy, particularly when the data is stored on cloud services susceptible to adversaries. To mitigate these risks, a proposal to encrypt recovery data using the DKG protocol seed has emerged, aiming to enhance security without complicating participant responsibilities. More details can be found [here](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/7084f935-0201-4909-99ff-c76f83572a7c@gmail.com/T/#m18a9fed80605ff3d2ff482c938c53db65d963248).

In another discussion, /dev /fd0 introduces Octojoin, a novel approach designed to preserve transaction privacy within the Bitcoin network. By incorporating multiple inputs from various users into a single transaction, Octojoin complicates the process for on-chain analysts trying to determine ownership, thereby enhancing privacy. This method, which draws an analogy to an octopus's camouflage ability, not only aims to obscure transaction histories but also encourages the usage of swaps and the sale of statecoins derived from coinjoined UTXOs. Further information on Octojoin and its development is available at [https://octojoin.github.io/](https://octojoin.github.io/).

recent_posts.title: BIP Draft: "ChillDKG: Distributed Key Generation for FROST"
recent_posts.summary:
- The email outlines privacy issues in DKG involving plaintext sensitive information.
- Current protocols omit encryption of DKG recovery data, posing privacy risks.
- It suggests using the DKG protocol seed for encryption to improve security.

recent_posts.title: Octojoin: Payjoin with no interaction between sender and recipient
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin developers are addressing privacy issues in transactions using Payjoin.
- Octojoin, a proposed solution, allows multiple-user inputs in one transaction to enhance privacy.
- It aims to make transactions indistinct from regular ones, promoting privacy and swap usage.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Poinsot launched a discussion on the Great Consensus Cleanup on DelvingBitcoin.org.
- He proposes limiting legacy transaction sizes to address block validation time concerns.
- Poinsot also considers fixing the timewarp bug and ensuring coinbase transaction uniqueness vital.

active_posts.title: A "Free" Relay Attack Taking Advantage of The Lack of Full-RBF In Core
active_posts.summary:
- Peter Todd disclosed a vulnerability in Bitcoin's transaction relay system, urging a fix.
- He suggests fully enabling Replace-By-Fee to mitigate free relay attacks, a solution ignored for political reasons.
- Todd criticizes the Bitcoin Core team's disregard for security vulnerabilities and ineffective decision-making processes.

active_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal introduces a quantum-resistant signature algorithm for Bitcoin's security enhancement.
- It aims to initiate a series of BIPs for the "QuBit" soft fork, engaging community feedback.
- The document is open for review to develop concrete solutions against quantum threats.

active_posts.title: Segwit Ephemeral Anchors
active_posts.summary:
- Ephemeral Anchors create "dusty" value outputs relying on Bitcoin's legacy script, raising security issues.
- Initial solutions add inefficiency, while a new proposal offers a compact, softfork-based method.
- This approach, detailed on GitHub, requires minimal byte addition and awaits relay policy changes.

active_posts.title: Ephemeral Anchors and MEVil
active_posts.summary:
- An anomaly in blockchain's "anti-MEVil" mechanism can lead to peculiar transaction issues.
- Bob's use of Alice's funds against `TxD` is an example highlighting the mechanism's flaw.
- Anti-DoS rules unintentionally incentivize inflating ephemeral anchor values, affecting transactions.

today_in_history_posts.title: Proposal: Demonstration of Phase in Full Network Upgrade Activated by Miners
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Switching to Proof of Stake could limit competition and create barriers, decreasing Bitcoin's economy health.
- Competition among miners, crucial for Bitcoin's security, remains vibrant despite industrial scaling.
- The writer believes hard forks are manageable, suggesting waiting for the dominant chain ensures transaction security.

today_in_history_posts.title: BOLT 11, real time micro payments, and route redundancy
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Andy Schroder asks why BOLT 11 lacks BIP 70's refund address option.
- He discusses adapting his fuel pump for Lightning with necessary refund capabilities.
- Schroder explores real-time micropayments for cars, questioning latency and automatic failovers.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability involves creating 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for 1 billion weekly users.
- These entities range from federated sidechains to coinpools, enhancing transactions without central trust.
- The approach integrates sidechains and Layer 2 protocols, maintaining Bitcoin's core as inflation-resistant.
